channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Defends Decision to Announce Missing Soldier’s Death
item.description: As operations to destroy tunnels continued, the Israeli military said DNA tests had been carried out on remains found after a lieutenant and two colleagues were attacked.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Putin Strives to Harness Energy of Russian Pilgrims for Political Profit
item.description: Celebrations for the 700th birthday of St. Sergius emphasized his role in shaping a unified Russia, a narrative that dovetails with the Kremlin’s political aims.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians gathered last month in Sergiyev Posad for a pilgrimage to Trinity Lavra of St. Sergius, the seat of the Russian Orthodox faith and the country’s original monastery.

item.title: Hospitals in Gaza Overwhelmed as Attacks Continue
item.description: More than 120 Palestinians were killed in Rafah, Gaza Strip, on Friday and Saturday. Those deaths, and hundreds of injuries, overwhelmed the city’s health care facilities.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and FARES AKRAM
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Medics at a field hospital in Rafah, Gaza Strip. More than 120 Palestinians were killed in Rafah alone on Friday and Saturday.

item.title: Missing Soldier Killed in Battle, Israel Confirms
item.description: The Israeli military said the soldier who had been thought captured by Palestinian militants during a deadly clash on Friday was now considered to have been killed in battle.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers watching Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speak on television at a coffee shop near the border with Gaza.

item.title: Gunmen From Syria Hit Army Checkpoints in Lebanon
item.description: Security posts and homes were also attacked on Saturday by gunmen who were thought to be Syrian rebel fighters working to win the release of one of their own.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Gunmen on Saturday driving away with men in Arsal, a border town in northeastern Lebanon near Syria. Gunmen, identified as rebel fighters from Syria, attacked nine checkpoints, seizing some members of the security forces, Lebanese officials said.

item.title: U.S. Nuclear Deal With Russia Is Derailed as Tensions Rise
item.description: The growing confrontation between the United States and Russia has derailed an accord to expand collaboration on nuclear projects, including reciprocal visits to atomic sites by scientists.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.media:description: Under the arrangement, Russian scientists would have been allowed into, among other places, the heart of the American nuclear complex at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico.

item.title: China Experiences a Booming Underground Market in Child Surrogacy
item.description: The rise of surrogacy links wealthy couples with poor women, in a murky world of online brokers, dubious private clinics and expensive trips to foreign countries.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 30-year-old rural woman who asked to go by her surname, Kong, is six months pregnant and will earn $24,000 as a Baby Plan surrogate.

item.title: Otherworldly Downpour Preceded Landslide in India
item.description: Severe weather hit South Asia in recent days, but the reason for the landslide, in which 158 people were feared dead, was unclear even four days later.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: The Indian National Disaster Response Force has recovered at least 82 bodies after a landslide in a village in western India.

item.title: Hope Dwindles for Hondurans Living in Peril
item.description: Residents of Chamelecón, the most dangerous neighborhood in one of the most dangerous cities in the hemisphere, face a daily grind of murder and mayhem.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: News Analysis: The War of Words in China
item.description: After a lull in xenophobia, anti-Western invective is back.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Opinion: Facebook’s Gateway Drug
item.description: The company’s plan to get the world online sounds good. But it’s all about money.
item.dc:creator: By EVGENY MOROZOV

item.title: Quick History: This Time, a Different Kind of War Between Israel and Hamas
item.description: With the collapse of a 72-hour cease-fire, it is difficult to see how the bloodshed can be stopped.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry faces an increasingly uphill battle in his cease-fire negotiations.

item.title: More Remains Found at Ukraine Crash Site
item.description: After delays, Dutch and Australian police officers and forensic experts are searching the wreckage of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Villagers walk along the road between Donetsk and the crash site of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in eastern Ukraine on Saturday.

item.title: Landslide in Nepal Kills at Least 8; Hundreds Are Missing
item.description: The landslide near the Chinese border washed out a crucial highway and blocked a river, leading to a dangerous buildup of water.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Explosion Kills Dozens at Eastern China Plant
item.description: At least 68 people were killed Saturday morning when a blast tore through a metal products factory in China’s eastern Jiangsu Province, state-run news media reported.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Medical personnel transported a victim to a hospital after an explosion at a factory in Kunshan, Jiangsu Province, in China.

item.title: World Briefing: China: Blast at Work Site Kills Dozens
item.description: An explosion killed between 40 and 65 people at a workshop in an eastern Chinese city, China state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: The Netherlands: A Greenpeace Ship Heads Home After a Russian Ordeal
item.description: The Greenpeace ship departed for the Netherlands nearly a year after Russian authorities seized it during a protest against an oil platform, Greenpeace International said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea’s Antipathy for the U.S. Is Seen at a New High
item.description: North Korea’s deputy permanent representative, Ri Tong-il, recited grievances with the United States and South Korea, accusing them of conspiring for regime change in the North.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Japan: Names Given to Disputed Islands
item.description: Japan on Friday gave names to five uninhabited islets in an island group at the center of a territorial dispute with China as part of efforts to reinforce its claim, drawing quick condemnation from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Birthright Trips to Israel Continue Despite Mideast Conflict
item.description: There have been some cancellations since the hostilities began, but 6,000 young people have visited Israel as planned.
item.dc:creator: By ELENA SCHNEIDER
item.media:description: Lila Faria, 19, at her home in Maplewood, N.J. Ms. Faria, a student at New York University, recently returned from a trip to the Middle East with the Taglit-Birthright Israel organization.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: A Creole Solution for Haiti’s Woes
item.description: Children should learn in the language they speak at home, not French.
item.dc:creator: By MICHEL DeGRAFF and MOLLY RUGGLES

item.title: Anti-Semitism Rises in Europe Amid Israel-Gaza Conflict
item.description: Attacks, threats and hate speech have yielded alarm among many Jews and stern language from government leaders.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: Protesters in support of Palestinians in Gaza last weekend displayed a swastika at a Paris rally. The demonstration had been banned by the government and prompted deployment of police.

item.title: Britain Fails to Find Riches It Expected in Swiss Accounts
item.description: When the British tax authorities struck a landmark deal with the Swiss to crack down on tax evasion, they sat back and waited for the cash to flow in. Almost three years later, they are still waiting.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Niels Ackermann for The New York Times
item.media:description: The banking industry in Zurich is centered on a square called Paradeplatz, where companies like Credit Suisse are based.

item.title: Gaza Fighting Intensifies as Cease-Fire Falls Apart
item.description: A cease-fire in Gaza collapsed on Friday as the Israeli military said that two soldiers had been killed and a third apparently captured. Gaza health officials said at least 70 Palestinians had been killed by Israeli airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli officials said Second Lt. Hadar Goldin was abducted; two other soldiers were killed.

item.title: A Test for Ukraine in a City Retaken From Rebels
item.description: In Slovyansk, a city of 80,000 that was a stronghold for pro-Russian rebels, Ukraine authorities have a difficult task ahead to shift the loyalties of residents to keep the peace.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nadezda Ivanovna, 84, of Slovyansk, a city held by pro-Russian rebels who have since fled.
